p.span: April 24, 2020
Dear Raytown Schools Families

I recently shared a video message with you following Governor Parsons closing of Missouri schools for the rest of the school year. Over the past two weeks, the Board of Education, district leadership, school administrators, teachers, and staff have been working to create a plan for the rest of the school year and answer questions raised by this announcement. I am writing to you to provide an update on decisions made over the past two weeks.

We confirmed that the last day of school for students in grades PK-11 is Wednesday, May 20. The last day for seniors is Friday, May 8. Virtual Learning instruction will now take place four days a week - Monday-Thursday. Fridays are used for staff collaboration, professional development and planning. Fridays also allow teachers to make individual contact with their students. We will continue to serve meals 11:30-1 p.m. Monday-Friday, through June 30, 2020.

Schools are working on plans to bring in students and families to pick up personal items and medication following the last day of virtual learning. Students and families will be brought in in small groups to ensure social distancing practices are upheld during this time. More information will be shared with families by their child's school in the weeks to come. Please keep in mind that these plans are dependent upon local legislators plans for reopening.

On Thursday, April 16, County Executive Frank White, Jr. extended Jackson Countys stay-at-home orders through May 15. The extension came after regional public health officers issued a recommendation to extend local stay-at-home orders to slow the spread of COVID-19. The countys plan for reopening will take a tiered approach, slowly increasing the size of group gatherings. With that in mind, we have begun to look at dates in July for many events and activities normally taking place in May and June.

We are planning for Smart Start Summer School to take place July 6-31. Our program will continue its traditional design to give all students a Smart Start to the fall semester. The program will help students maintain the skills they acquired during the regular school year and further obtain new skills for the upcoming school year.

In June, we will offer online courses for students in grades 9-12 to earn first time credit, recover credit, or learn more about a particular topic during the summer. For most courses, high school students can earn a unit of credit for successfully passing, and their course grade contributes to their overall high school GPA.
Enrollment is going on now for Smart Start Summer School for students entering Kindergarten through 12 grade in the fall of 2020. For more information and to enroll your child, please visit

The District is committed to celebrating our seniors. The District will provide Class of 2020 graduates with a personalized yard sign, featuring the students name and photo. These signs will be provided at no cost to our families. We will share more information about how we plan to distribute these signs in the next two weeks.

We are committed to exploring every possible opportunity to host an in person graduation. We originally secured May 19 and 20 for graduation after the venue cancelled our original dates. With stay-at-home orders extended through May 15, we have begun seeking dates in July. As it stands, we have confirmed Sunday, July 26 as our date for graduation. Raytown Highs Graduation will begin at 2:00 p.m. and Raytown South Highs graduation will begin at 4:30 p.m. Both ceremonies are scheduled to take place at the Silverstein Eye Centers Arena located at 19100 E Valley View Pkwy, Independence, MO 64055. Additional communication will be provided to seniors and their families regarding graduation. We are also exploring options for virtual graduation. We recognize that there are a number of senior activities that create life-long memories for our graduates. We are looking for ways to reschedule those activities through both traditional and virtual avenues.
Pre-Kindergarten (Pre-K) and Kindergarten enrollment for the 2020-2021 school year is currently open.
All Families (new, returning, and Form 2) can enroll online and submit required documents via email to

. New and Form 2 families will receive an email with dates in July and August to visit the Enrollment Center in person to validate documents sent via email. For more information about Residency and Enrollment, please visit

There is still work to be done to answer all of the unknowns. Thank you for your continued support of the Raytown School District. Please Stay Safe, Stay Strong and Stay Home - we will all get through this together.
Sincerely,
Superintendent of Schools

div.p: PK-2 Flexible Learning Packets for weeks six (6), seven (7) and eight (8) will be available for pick up at all preschools and elementary schools after 1:00 p.m. on Monday, April 27. They will be available at a self-serve location outside of the school 24 hours a day. Packets will also be available through the lunch lines starting on Tuesday, April 28. These same packets are available electronically on the Virtual Learning Portal.

p.span: Based on the results of staff, student, and parent surveys, the District will modify the schedule for virtual learning days effective this week. Virtual Learning instruction will now take place four (4) days a week - Monday-Thursday. Fridays will now be used for staff collaboration, professional development and planning. This day will also allow teachers to make individual contact with their students.

div.p: The last day of school for student PK-11 will be Wednesday, May 20.
The last day for seniors is Friday, May 8.
Meals will continue to be served from 11:30-1 p.m. Monday-Friday.

li.span: Secondary
We will follow a Hold Harmless model so that students can improve their grade but will not be penalized for lack of participation.
Grades entered into the gradebook for assignments submitted through March 13th were graded and entered into SISK12 as normal.

Assignments given for March 24 - April 3 were graded and entered into SISK12. The difference was that assignments not completed were entered as Exempt so students were not penalized for not completing the assignment.
The grading period ended on April 3 with grades stored on April 7th so grades were set at that point.
Grade cards were mailed or emailed home with this grade on April 13th.

Assignments given after April 3 will be collected, graded and entered into SISK12 as normal with students receiving a 0 for not completing an assignment. Grades will continue to be cumulative for the entire semester.
Teachers will give students the higher grade for their final semester grade between the grade on the progress report that we sent home on April 13th or the cumulative semester grade.
Elementary

We sent a progress report home by mail or email on April 13th for the third quarter along with a note. The note stated that we will not have a progress report for 4th quarter because we will not be able to properly evaluate students mastery of skills.
Teachers will continue to give feedback as much as possible on an individual basis for grades 3-5 based on student work.
Teachers are not collecting any work for PK-2 and will have no basis for any conversations on student progress.

p.span: Based on the results of staff, student, and parent surveys, the District will modify the schedule for virtual learning days effective this week. Virtual Learning instruction will now take place four (4) days a week - Monday-Thursday. Fridays will now be used for staff collaboration, professional development and planning. This day will also allow teachers to make individual contact with their students.
The last day of school for student PK-11 will be Wednesday, May 20.

div.p: The last day for seniors is Friday, May 8.

p.span: Meals will continue to be served from 11:30-1 p.m. Monday-Friday.

li.span: Secondary
We will follow a Hold Harmless model so that students can improve their grade but will not be penalized for lack of participation.
Grades entered into the gradebook for assignments submitted through March 13th were graded and entered into SISK12 as normal.

Assignments given for March 24 - April 3 were graded and entered into SISK12. The difference was that assignments not completed were entered as Exempt so students were not penalized for not completing the assignment.
The grading period ended on April 3 with grades stored on April 7th so grades were set at that point.
Grade cards were mailed or emailed home with this grade on April 13th.

Assignments given after April 3 will be collected, graded and entered into SISK12 as normal with students receiving a 0 for not completing an assignment. Grades will continue to be cumulative for the entire semester.
Teachers will give students the higher grade for their final semester grade between the grade on the progress report that we sent home on April 13th or the cumulative semester grade.
Elementary

We sent a progress report home by mail or email on April 13th for the third quarter along with a note. The note stated that we will not have a progress report for 4th quarter because we will not be able to properly evaluate students mastery of skills.
Teachers will continue to give feedback as much as possible on an individual basis for grades 3-5 based on student work.
Teachers are not collecting any work for PK-2 and will have no basis for any conversations on student progress.

p.span: Missourians in need can find essential services, such as nearly 240 food pantries, food banks, school meal programs for students, diaper banks, and more through the online

system. The Services Navigator offers instant access to programs and services available in Missouri. There are currently over 2,000 services listed, with new services added daily. Searches can be keyword, location, and/or service. Every program and service contains a map of the location as well as contact information.
The City of Independence also offers a
to connect community members with local available services.

p.b: How to Talk to Children about COVID-19 Live Q&A

p.span: The Jackson County Health and Truman Medical Centers will host a live Question and Answer session on Friday, April 17 on how to talk to children about COVID-19, how to deal with stress related to the situation, how to identify warning signs, resources, etc. You can join the event on Facebook Live at
or YouTube Live at
on Friday, April 17 from 10-10:30 a.m.
Pre-Kindergarten (Pre-K) and Kindergarten enrollment for the 2020-2021 school year is currently open.
All Families (new, returning, and Form 2) can enroll online and submit required documents via email to
. New and Form 2 families will receive an email with dates in July and August to visit the Enrollment Center in person to validate documents sent via email.
For more information about Residency and Enrollment, please click

h1.aria-label: How to Talk to Children about COVID-19 Live Q&A

div.h1: How to Talk to Children about COVID-19 Live Q&A

div.p: The Jackson County Health and Truman Medical Centers will host a live Question and Answer session on Friday, April 17 on how to talk to children about COVID-19, how to deal with stress related to the situation, how to identify warning signs, resources, etc. You can join the event on Facebook Live at indep.us/facebook or YouTube Live at indep.us/youtube on Friday, April 17 from 10-10:30 a.m.

div.div: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommends the use of cloth face coverings to slow the spread of COVID-19. In light of new evidence showing that individuals who lack symptoms can transmit the virus to others before showing symptoms, the CDC recommends wearing a cloth face covering to protect the nose and mouth in public settings where other social distancing measures are difficult to maintain.

div.p: Wearing a face covering does not prevent the critical need to maintain 6-feet social distancing to slow the spread of the virus. Cloth face coverings fashioned from household items or made at home from common materials at low cost can be used as an additional, voluntary public health measure. The cloth face coverings recommended are not surgical masks or N-95 respirators. Those are critical supplies that must continue to be reserved for healthcare workers and other medical first responders, as recommended by current CDC guidance.

Please note: Cloth face coverings should not be placed on young children younger than 2 years of age, anyone who has trouble breathing, or is unconscious, incapacitated or otherwise unable to remove the cover without assistance.

RQS employees involved in the preparation and distribution of daily meals are required to wear a face covering at all times while at work. All other essential employees reporting to district facilities are strongly encouraged to wear a face covering while at work. All employees should continue to observe social distancing practices as well as frequent hand washing and sanitation.

Below are a list of resources to assist in creating and safely maintaining a face covering made of household materials. While there is no recommendation from the CDC for the general public to wear gloves, below are also a few resources related to glove use as contamination during glove removal is common.

p.strong: CDC Recommendation w/ video from the Surgeon General
How to Correctly Wear Face Coverings and Gloves for COVID-19
How to Wear and Discard a Face Covering
How to Safely Remove Used Gloves

p.span: As information unfolds regarding the coronavirus, any individual can experience a wide range of thoughts and emotions including fear and anxiety. According to the CDC, People who may respond more strongly to the stress of a crisis include:

li.span: Older people and people with chronic diseases who are at higher risk for COVID-19
Children and teens
People who are helping with the response to COVID-19, like doctors and other health care providers, or first responders
People who have mental health conditions including problems with substance use

p.span: Stress during an infectious disease outbreak can include

li.span: Fear and worry about your own health and the health of your loved ones
Changes in sleep or eating patterns
Difficulty sleeping or concentrating
Worsening of chronic health problems
Increased use of alcohol, tobacco, or other drugs

p.span: Taking care of yourself, your friends, and your family can help you cope with stress. Helping others cope with their stress can also make your community stronger. Things you can do to support yourself:

li.span: Take breaks from watching, reading, or listening to news stories, including social media. Hearing about the pandemic repeatedly can be upsetting.
Take care of your body. Take deep breaths, stretch, or meditate. Try to eat healthy, well-balanced meals, exercise regularly, get plenty of sleep, and avoid alcohol and drugs.
Make time to unwind. Try to do some other activities you enjoy.
Connect with others. Talk with people you trust about your concerns and how you are feeling.
Call your healthcare provider if stress gets in the way of your daily activities for several days in a row.

p.span: Children and teens react, in part, on what they see from the adults around them. When parents and caregivers deal with the COVID-19 calmly and confidently, they can provide the best support for their children. Parents can be more reassuring to others around them, especially children, if they are better prepared. Not all children and teens respond to stress in the same way. Some common changes to watch for include:

li.span: Excessive crying or irritation in younger children
Returning to behaviors they have outgrown (for example, toileting accidents or bedwetting)
Excessive worry or sadness
Unhealthy eating or sleeping habits
Irritability and acting out behaviors in teens
Poor school performance or avoiding school
Difficulty with attention and concentration
Avoidance of activities enjoyed in the past
Unexplained headaches or body pain
Use of alcohol, tobacco, or other drugs

p.span: There are many things you can do to support your child:

li.span: Take time to talk with your child or teen about the COVID-19 outbreak. Answer questions and share facts about COVID-19 in a way that your child or teen can understand.
Reassure your child or teen that they are safe. Let them know it is ok if they feel upset. Share with them how you deal with your own stress so that they can learn how to cope from you.
Limit your familys exposure to news coverage of the event, including social media. Children may misinterpret what they hear and can be frightened about something they do not understand.
Try to keep up with regular routines. If schools are closed, create a schedule for learning activities and relaxing or fun activities.
Be a role model. Take breaks, get plenty of sleep, exercise, and eat well. Connect with your friends and family members.
Learn more about helping children cope.

p.span: If there is a crisis or emergency during the time of the closure, students and families can access the supports below:

li.span: Disaster Distress Helpline
Text: "TalkWithUs" to 66746

p.span: We know that this is a challenging time. The District will continue to share information through the website, social media, and email.

div.p: In an effort for the Raytown School District Student Health Services Department to streamline the process for our students who may need medications currently housed in our school clinics, you can pick up your childs medication from 9 a.m. 12 p.m. at your childs school on Monday, March 30. This will be the last day for medication pickup before we return to school. Medication pickup will be unavailable at Raytown Middle School.

Parents/guardians and students will not have access to any part of our school buildings during this time. Families will be asked to call their childs school when they arrive and wait in their vehicles outside the main entrance of the building for the school nurse to deliver their childs medication to them. We ask those waiting outside to comply with social distancing and safety protocols and to please stay in their vehicles at all times.
If you have any questions or concerns, please emaildistrictnurses@raytownschools.org.

p.span: We are in close contact with the Missouri Department of Elementary and Secondary Education (DESE). There are a number of decisions that need to be made to support our students. More information will be coming soon. Please visit DESEs website for more information:
The state has made the decision to not offer state testing this year. Please visit DESEs website for more information:

Raytown High School and Raytown South High School graduations will be postponed until a later date. Silverstein Arena, our graduation venue, has offered alternative dates to be approved by the Board of Education. We will send out more information once we are able to confirm a date for each high school. Seniors will get more information directly as it becomes available.

The Raytown School District follows a centralized enrollment process, which starts at the Residency Office and is an individualized process for each family. All students must live within the school district boundaries, submit the required documents to the Residency Office, and submit an online registration to complete the enrollment process.
Please note, the Enrollment Center is closed when the District is closed.
Pre-Kindergarten (Pre-K) and Kindergarten enrollment for the 2020-2021 school year is currently open.
All Families (new, returning, and Form 2) can enroll online and submit required documents via email to
. New and Form 2 families will receive an email with dates in July and August
to visit the Enrollment Center in person to validate documents sent via email.
families who are are new to the District for the 19-20 school year, please visithttp://bit.ly/2YZr5G3or contact Residency at
residency@raytownschools.org.

div.script: $(document).ready(function() {CheckScript('ModuleView');CheckScript('Mustache'); });

p.span: We encourage families to ensure students have access to the internet at home, should the District close for an extended period of time. Some internet providers are offering free, low or reduced cost programs and resources for families. Please follow the links below for more information.

div.script: $(document).ready(function() {CheckScript('ModuleView');CheckScript('Mustache'); });

p.span: You first put in your zip code and then you check all that apply. For more information, please visit

div.p: https://www.everyoneon.org/find-offers.

Shop internet service providers and compare dozens of internet options and choose the best one for your home with your zip code. Call one of their experts who can make a recommendation based on your needs or take your order by phone at 1-888-209-5085.

As the country deals with the effects of the Coronavirus (COVID-19), Comcast is taking immediate steps to help connect more low-income families to the Internet at home. Effective Monday, March 16, 2020, anyone who signs up for Internet Essentials will receive two free months of Internet service. Comcast is also increasing the speed of the program to 25 Mbps downloads, and 3 Mbps uploads for all new and existing customers.

After your first two free months expire, you can either cancel the service (which you can do at any time) or keep it as a regular paying Internet Essentials customer. You will receive an easy to use self-install-kit that includes a cable modem (to receive service at your home) with a WiFi router (to connect your devices without wires). There is no term contract or credit check and no shipping fee for equipment.
10 megabits per second $10 per month, 5 megabits per second, for $10 per month, 3 megabits per second, for $5 per month.

Charter will offer free Spectrum broadband and Wi-Fi access for 60 days to households with K-12 and/or college students who do not already have a Spectrum broadband subscription at any service level up to 100 Mbps.To enroll call 1-844-488-8395.Installation fees will be waived for new student households.
